content.code: Deals with the physical connection between devices (e.g., cables, switches).
Handles node-to-node data transfer (e.g., MAC addresses, Ethernet).
Manages device addressing and routing (e.g., IP addresses, routers).
Ensures reliable data transfer (e.g., TCP, UDP).
Manages sessions between applications (e.g., RPC, NetBIOS).
Handles data formatting and encryption (e.g., SSL, JPEG).
Provides network services to applications (e.g., HTTP, FTP).
Combines OSI's Physical and Data Link layers.
Corresponds to OSI's Network layer (e.g., IP, ICMP).
Corresponds to OSI's Transport layer (e.g., TCP, UDP).
Combines OSI's Session, Presentation, and Application layers (e.g., HTTP, FTP).
Divides an IP network into smaller networks (e.g., 192.168.1.0/24).
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (Secure) for web communication.
File Transfer Protocol for file transfers.
Domain Name System for resolving domain names to IP addresses.
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for automatic IP assignment.
Connects different networks and routes data between them.
Connects devices within a network and forwards data based on MAC addresses.
Connects devices within a network but broadcasts data to all devices.
Filters incoming and outgoing network traffic based on security rules.
All devices are connected to a central hub or switch.
All devices are connected to a single communication line.
Each device is connected to two other devices, forming a ring.
Each device is connected to every other device in the network.
Port 80
Port 443
Port 21
Port 22
Filters incoming and outgoing traffic based on predefined rules.
Creates a secure, encrypted connection over the internet.
Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems monitor and block malicious activity.
802.11a/b/g/n/ac/ax (Wi-Fi 6).
Service Set Identifier: The name of a wireless network.
Wi-Fi Protected Access protocols for securing wireless networks.
